intro: Bartschella napina, commonly known as the narrowleaf bartschella, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. The plant features slender, hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves with a distinctively narrow form. Its small, white to pale yellow flowers are arranged in compact umbels, and it produces small, dry fruits known as schizocarps. Bartschella napina is often found in temperate regions of North America and is valued for its ecological role in supporting pollinators and soil stability.
